00008   if(!strcasecmp(alloc_opt_string,"STM"))
00009     return new core_alloc_STM_t(core);
00010 #else

00012 class core_alloc_STM_t:public core_alloc_t
00013 {
00014   enum alloc_stall_t {ASTALL_NONE,   /* no stall */
00015                       ASTALL_EMPTY,
00016                       ASTALL_ROB,
00017                       ASTALL_LDQ,
00018                       ASTALL_STQ,
00019                       ASTALL_RS,
00020                       ASTALL_DRAIN,
00021                       ASTALL_num
00022                      };
00023 
00024   public:
00025 
00026   core_alloc_STM_t(struct core_t * const core);
00027   virtual void reg_stats(struct stat_sdb_t * const sdb);
00028 
00029   virtual void step(void);
00030   virtual void recover(void);
00031   virtual void recover(const struct Mop_t * const Mop);
00032 
00033   virtual void RS_deallocate(const struct uop_t * const uop);
00034   virtual void start_drain(void); /* prevent allocation from proceeding to exec */
00035 
00036   protected:
00037 
00038   /* for load-balancing port binding */
00039   int * port_loading;
00040 
00041   static const char *alloc_stall_str[ASTALL_num];
00042 };
00043 
00044 const char *core_alloc_STM_t::alloc_stall_str[ASTALL_num] = {
00045   "no stall                   ",
00046   "no uops to allocate        ",
00047   "ROB is full                ",
00048   "LDQ is full                ",
00049   "STQ is full                ",
00050   "RS is full                 ",
00051   "OOO core draining          "
00052 };

00054 /*******************/

00057 
00058 core_alloc_STM_t::core_alloc_STM_t(struct core_t * const arg_core)
00059 {
00060   struct core_knobs_t * knobs = arg_core->knobs;
00061   core = arg_core;
00062 
00063   port_loading = (int*) calloc(knobs->exec.num_exec_ports,sizeof(*port_loading));
00064   if(!port_loading)
00065     fatal("couldn't calloc allocation port-loading scoreboard");
00066 }
00067 
00068 void
00069 core_alloc_STM_t::reg_stats(struct stat_sdb_t * const sdb)
00070 {
00071   char buf[1024];
00072   char buf2[1024];
00073   struct thread_t * arch = core->current_thread;
00074 
00075   stat_reg_note(sdb,"#### ALLOC STATS ####");
00076   sprintf(buf,"c%d.alloc_insn",arch->id);
00077   stat_reg_counter(sdb, true, buf, "total number of instructions alloced", &core->stat.alloc_insn, core->stat.alloc_insn, NULL);
00078   sprintf(buf,"c%d.alloc_uops",arch->id);
00079   stat_reg_counter(sdb, true, buf, "total number of uops alloced", &core->stat.alloc_uops, core->stat.alloc_uops, NULL);
00080   sprintf(buf,"c%d.alloc_IPC",arch->id);
00081   sprintf(buf2,"c%d.alloc_insn/c%d.sim_cycle",arch->id,arch->id);
00082   stat_reg_formula(sdb, true, buf, "IPC at alloc", buf2, NULL);
00083   sprintf(buf,"c%d.alloc_uPC",arch->id);
00084   sprintf(buf2,"c%d.alloc_uops/c%d.sim_cycle",arch->id,arch->id);
00085   stat_reg_formula(sdb, true, buf, "uPC at alloc", buf2, NULL);
00086 
00087   sprintf(buf,"c%d.alloc_stall",core->current_thread->id);
00088   core->stat.alloc_stall = stat_reg_dist(sdb, buf,
00089                                           "breakdown of stalls at alloc",
00090                                           /* initial value */0,
00091                                           /* array size */ASTALL_num,
00092                                           /* bucket size */1,
00093                                           /* print format */(PF_COUNT|PF_PDF),
00094                                           /* format */NULL,
00095                                           /* index map */alloc_stall_str,
00096                                           /* print fn */NULL);
00097 }

00103 
00104 void core_alloc_STM_t::step(void)
00105 {
00106   struct core_knobs_t * knobs = core->knobs;
00107   enum alloc_stall_t stall_reason = ASTALL_NONE;
00108 
00109   /*========================================================================*/
00110   /*== Dispatch insts if ROB, RS, and LQ/SQ entries available (as needed) ==*/
00111   if(core->decode->uop_available()) /* are there uops in the decode stage? */
00112   {
00113     /* if using drain flush: */
00114     /* is the back-end still draining from a misprediction recovery? */
00115     if(knobs->alloc.drain_flush && drain_in_progress)
00116     {
00117       if(!core->commit->ROB_empty())
00118       {
00119         stall_reason = ASTALL_DRAIN;
00120         ZESTO_STAT(stat_add_sample(core->stat.alloc_stall, (int)stall_reason);)
00121         return;
00122       }
00123       else
00124         drain_in_progress = false;
00125     }
00126 
00127     for(int i=0; i < knobs->alloc.width; i++) /* if so, scan all slots (width) of this stage */
00128     {
00129       struct uop_t * uop = core->decode->uop_peek();
00130 
00131       zesto_assert(uop->timing.when_allocated == TICK_T_MAX,(void)0);
00132 
00133       /* is the ROB full? */
00134       if(!core->commit->ROB_available())
00135       {
00136         stall_reason = ASTALL_ROB;
00137         break;
00138       }
00139 
00140       /* for loads, is the LDQ full? */
00141       if(uop->decode.is_load && !core->exec->LDQ_available())
00142       {
00143         stall_reason = ASTALL_LDQ;
00144         break;
00145       }
00146       /* for stores, allocate STQ entry on STA.  NOTE: This is different from 
00147          Bob Colwell's description in Shen&Lipasti Chap 7 where he describes
00148          allocation on STD.  We emit STA uops first since the oracle needs to
00149          use the STA result to feed the following STD uop. */
00150       if(uop->decode.is_sta && !core->exec->STQ_available())
00151       {
00152         stall_reason = ASTALL_STQ;
00153         break;
00154       }
00155 
00156       /* is the RS full? -- don't need to alloc for NOP's */
00157       if(!uop->decode.is_nop && !core->exec->RS_available())
00158       {
00159         stall_reason = ASTALL_RS;
00160         break;
00161       }
00162 
00163       /* ALL ALLOC STALL CONDITIONS PASSED */
00164       core->decode->uop_consume();
00165 
00166       /* place in ROB */
00167       core->commit->ROB_insert(uop);
00168 
00169       /* place in LDQ/STQ if needed */
00170       if(uop->decode.is_load)
00171         core->exec->LDQ_insert(uop);
00172       else if(uop->decode.is_sta)
00173         core->exec->STQ_insert_sta(uop);
00174       else if(uop->decode.is_std)
00175         core->exec->STQ_insert_std(uop);
00176 
00177       /* all store uops had better be marked is_std */
00178       zesto_assert((!(uop->decode.opflags & F_STORE)) || uop->decode.is_std,(void)0);
00179       zesto_assert((!(uop->decode.opflags & F_LOAD)) || uop->decode.is_load,(void)0);
00180 
00181       /* port bindings */
00182       if(!uop->decode.is_nop && !uop->Mop->decode.is_trap)
00183       {
00184         /* port-binding is trivial when there's only one valid port */
00185         if(knobs->exec.port_binding[uop->decode.FU_class].num_FUs == 1)
00186         {
00187           uop->alloc.port_assignment = knobs->exec.port_binding[uop->decode.FU_class].ports[0];
00188         }
00189         else /* else assign uop to least loaded port */
00190         {
00191           int min_load = INT_MAX;
00192           int index = -1;
00193           for(int j=0;j<knobs->exec.port_binding[uop->decode.FU_class].num_FUs;j++)
00194           {
00195             int port = knobs->exec.port_binding[uop->decode.FU_class].ports[j];
00196             if(port_loading[port] < min_load)
00197             {
00198               min_load = port_loading[port];
00199               index = port;
00200             }
00201           }
00202           uop->alloc.port_assignment = index;
00203         }
00204         port_loading[uop->alloc.port_assignment]++;
00205 
00206         core->exec->RS_insert(uop);
00207 
00208         /* Get input mappings - this is a proxy for explicit register numbers, which
00209            you can always get from idep_uop->alloc.ROB_index */
00210         for(int j=0;j<MAX_IDEPS;j++)
00211         {
00212           /* This use of oracle info is valid: at this point the processor would be
00213              looking up this information in the RAT, but this saves us having to
00214              explicitly store/track the RAT state. */
00215           uop->exec.idep_uop[j] = uop->oracle.idep_uop[j];
00216 
00217           /* Add self onto parent's output list.  This output list doesn't
00218              have a real microarchitectural counter part, but it makes the
00219              simulation faster by not having to perform a whole mess of
00220              associative searches each time any sort of broadcast is needed.
00221              The parent's odep list only points to uops which have dispatched
00222              into the OOO core (i.e. has left the alloc pipe). */
00223           if(uop->exec.idep_uop[j])
00224           {
00225             struct odep_t * odep = core->get_odep_link();
00226             odep->next = uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->exec.odep_uop;
00227             uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->exec.odep_uop = odep;
00228             odep->uop = uop;
00229             odep->aflags = (uop->decode.idep_name[j] == DCREG(MD_REG_AFLAGS));
00230             odep->op_num = j;
00231           }
00232         }
00233 
00234         /* check "scoreboard" for operand readiness (we're not actually
00235            explicitly implementing a scoreboard); if value is ready, read
00236            it into data-capture window or payload RAM. */
00237         tick_t when_ready = 0;
00238         for(int j=0;j<MAX_IDEPS;j++) /* for possible input argument */
00239         {
00240           if(uop->exec.idep_uop[j]) /* if the parent uop exists (i.e., still in the processor) */
00241           {
00242             uop->timing.when_ival_ready[j] = uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->timing.when_otag_ready;
00243             if(uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->exec.ovalue_valid)
00244             {
00245               uop->timing.when_ival_ready[j] = uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->timing.when_completed;
00246               uop->exec.ivalue_valid[j] = true;
00247               if(uop->decode.idep_name[j] == DCREG(MD_REG_AFLAGS))
00248                 uop->exec.ivalue[j].dw = uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->exec.oflags;
00249               else
00250                 uop->exec.ivalue[j] = uop->exec.idep_uop[j]->exec.ovalue;
00251             }
00252           }
00253           else /* read from ARF */
00254           {
00255             uop->timing.when_ival_ready[j] = sim_cycle;
00256             uop->exec.ivalue_valid[j] = true; /* applies to invalid (DNA) inputs as well */
00257             if(uop->decode.idep_name[j] != DNA)
00258               uop->exec.ivalue[j] = uop->oracle.ivalue[j]; /* oracle value == architected value */
00259           }
00260           if(when_ready < uop->timing.when_ival_ready[j])
00261             when_ready = uop->timing.when_ival_ready[j];
00262         }
00263         uop->timing.when_ready = when_ready;
00264         if(when_ready < TICK_T_MAX) /* add to readyQ if appropriate */
00265           core->exec->insert_ready_uop(uop);
00266       }
00267       else /* is_nop || is_trap */
00268       {
00269         /* NOP's don't go through exec pipeline; they go straight to the
00270            ROB and are immediately marked as completed (they still take
00271            up space in the ROB though). */
00272         /* Since traps/interrupts aren't really properly modeled in SimpleScalar, we just let
00273            it go through without doing anything. */
00274         uop->timing.when_ready = sim_cycle;
00275         uop->timing.when_issued = sim_cycle;
00276         uop->timing.when_completed = sim_cycle;
00277       }
00278 
00279       uop->timing.when_allocated = sim_cycle;
00280 
00281       /* update stats */
00282       if(uop->decode.EOM)
00283         ZESTO_STAT(core->stat.alloc_insn++;)
00284 
00285       ZESTO_STAT(core->stat.alloc_uops++;)
00286 
00287       if(!core->decode->uop_available())
00288         break;
00289     }
00290   }
00291   else
00292     stall_reason = ASTALL_EMPTY;
00293 
00294 
00295   ZESTO_STAT(stat_add_sample(core->stat.alloc_stall, (int)stall_reason);)
00296 }
00297 
00298 /* clean up on pipeline flush (blow everything away) */
00299 void
00300 core_alloc_STM_t::recover(void)
00301 {
00302   /* nothing to do */
00303 }
00304 void
00305 core_alloc_STM_t::recover(const struct Mop_t * const Mop)
00306 {
00307   /* nothing to do */
00308 }
00309 
00310 void core_alloc_STM_t::RS_deallocate(const struct uop_t * const uop)
00311 {
00312   zesto_assert(port_loading[uop->alloc.port_assignment] > 0,(void)0);
00313   port_loading[uop->alloc.port_assignment]--;
00314 }
00315 
00316 void core_alloc_STM_t::start_drain(void)
00317 {
00318   drain_in_progress = true;
00319 }
